docs.lead_paragraph: NO wonder this place is busy,'' blurted out a first-time visitor at the new Cafe Al Dente in Hicksville after looking at the menu's modest prices and then glancing at an adjacent table and seeing four jumbo bowls of pasta virtually crowding everything else off it. Those oversized soup bowls were piled high with pasta, most of it delivering blunt, big-shouldered flavors. This cozy 44-seat spot, which opened in December at 106 Woodbury Road (516-932-9788), is owned by Philip Morizio, the chef and part owner of Al Dente of Oyster Bay, where prices are slightly higher. At the Hicksville site, a bowl of pasta with a rambunctious marinara sauce, accompanied by an exceptional house salad, cost $10.95 and a sloppy, runny, but tasty, thin-crusted, classica pizza, loaded with lots of cheese and tomato sauce, went for $5.50. The peppy, already popular little Cafe Al Dente, with its bare tables, terra cotta floor, pressed-tin ceiling, fabric booths, faux brick wall and Italian family pictures, appeals to eaters, not diners, to people interested in value and taste, not prestige and status. It offers warm garlic and (commercial bakery) onion bread in baskets, glasses of complimentary wine on tables, a takeout following that rivals its sit-down clientele and the sound of popular classics sung by Tony Bennett, Frank Sinatra, Johnny Mathis and Johnny Ray.

docs.abstract: Letter from Culinary Institute of America professor Steven Koplan disputes May 9 Arts & Ideas article on development of French and English cuisine; says it wrongly implied that London only recently became most exciting restaurant city in Europe (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your May 9 Arts & Ideas article on the development of French and English cuisine implies that London has only recently become the most exciting restaurant city in Europe.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Your May 9 Arts & Ideas article on the development of French and English cuisine implies that London has only recently become the most exciting restaurant city in Europe....

docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill reports on cuisine of Vietnam; describes scene in Hue, once Vietnam's imperial city and long the epicenter of country's classic cuisine; photos; recipes (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: MOST of Vietnam is bathed by a constant gold sun that blesses the land with rich rice paddies and fields ripe with vegetables and fruit. But around Hue, in the central region of the country, the light is mauve and the harvest is more hardscrabble. Yet, Hue, once Vietnam's imperial city, has long been the epicenter of the country's classic cuisine. What the region lacks in bounty, its cooks have made up for in memory, taste and skill. There was, only 52 years ago, an Emperor to feed. And there was enough wealth to support an imperial staff of 50 cooks, who scoured the globe for rare ingredients and used precious saffron with abandon.
docs.snippet: MOST of Vietnam is bathed by a constant gold sun that blesses the land with rich rice paddies and fields ripe with vegetables and fruit. But around Hue, in the central region of the country, the light is mauve and the harvest is more hardscrabble....

docs.abstract: M H Reed reviews Lago di Como, Italian restaurant in Tarrytown, NY (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: ONCE, when overwhelmed by the stimuli of dramatic new eating spots, diners could reclaim their composure at Lago di Como. In understated surroundings this restaurant offered carefully wrought classic Northern Italian cuisine. The short menu is still true to this regional theme, listing dishes like polenta, calf's liver with onions, trout, scampi and chicken, among other classics. These days, however, it is difficult to attach a rating to this place, which, on one hand, can prepare a gorgeous dish of grouper without fault and, on the other, serve inedibly burned and desiccated scampi. Apparently, much depends on the skill and care provided by the kitchen on a given evening. Manage to order a meal composed of the best of every course, and you will have dined very well indeed. Under the circumstance, our findings might not necessarily correspond to those of other diners.

docs.lead_paragraph: VIETNAMESE cuisine is whetting appetites in New York, and not just in Asian enclaves. In the last couple of years, Vietnamese restaurants have opened in midtown, the Upper East and Upper West Sides, SoHo, Brooklyn Heights and Park Slope. At least six new establishments have crowds of eager customers willing to stand in line for tables. More places are on the way.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Brazilian cuisine has never caught fire in New York the way, say, Mexican food has, in part because there have never been more than a half-dozen Brazilian restaurants around town, most of them humble and homey. For those who want to try this gutsy maritime fare, though, ample opportunities exist.

docs.lead_paragraph: EVER so gradually, Italian restaurants are becoming trendy, and as new places open they begin to look more like Palazzo in Massapequa Park than those cliches decorated with flocked red wallpaper and paintings of gondolas. Palazzo's setting is sleek, tasteful and imaginative. The long, rather narrow room is suffused with rose pink, the restaurant color of the moment, done in wide incised horizontal bands. One section of the room is elevated and set off by gleaming metal railings, another of the latest in accents. Subdued gray carpeting, an eye-level swath of mirror and soft lighting from overhead industrial spots complete the simple, effective design. Instead of flowers, each table sports a tiny pink pineapple plant in a glass flask for an exotically color-coordinated touch.

docs.abstract: Announces agreement with Wrather Corp to use name and character of dog Lassie for a product being considered
docs.lead_paragraph: There has been a little rumor around that the Campbell Soup Company has been sniffing out the pet food business. Well, it's true, and the giant Camden, N. J., company announced yesterday that it had been licensed by the Wrather Corporation to use the name and character of Lassie for a product "under consideration and development."

docs.abstract: Richard Jay Scholem reviews B & B Polish Restaurant II in Lindenhurst, NY (A La Carte column) (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A HEARTY, Eastern European peasant food fix is what's offered at B&B Polish Restaurant II in Lindenhurst. It is a Weight Watcher's nightmare and a trencherman's fantasy. Despite the Island's substantial Polish population, especially on the East End, Polish restaurants remain a rare breed. Now one of the best, the tiny 11-year-old, order-at-the-counter B&B Polish Diner in Copiague has spawned a 200-seat counterpart at 485 Montauk Highway (631-226-3001). It features huge portions, minuscule prices, stick-to-your ribs dishes and, unlike the diner, waiters and tablecloths.

docs.abstract: Joanne Starkey reviews Maguro, Japanese restaurant in Roslyn, LI; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: IS Maguro the most expensive restaurant on the Island?'' asked the woman on the phone. ''We spent more there than at Panama Hatties,'' she said. That is easy to do when sushi assortments cost $30 to $70, the majority of hot entrees are $35 or more and appetizers (most in the teens) go as high as $25. The only way that reader escaped with next week's grocery money was by ordering a few hand rolls. (There are pitfalls here, too. The dragon roll is $20. It goes for $7 to $7.50 at nearby Japanese restaurants.) Maguro, a pleasant-looking corner spot in a shopping center on Old Northern Boulevard in Roslyn, gives no hint that it is different from other Long Island Japanese restaurants until diners sneak a peek at the menu. That menu calls the food nouvelle cuisine. It is certainly a far cry from typical Japanese fare. When have you last run across monkfish liver pate with daikon radish, grilled young bamboo served with aged soy sauce, crab-meat croquettes with tomato puree or steamed fluke drizzled with hot peanut oil?
